column10: Nice & Chill.
Once you get past the first few hours and can start grinding out fish packs its fun! Lots of run time because I've left it on overnight feeding my fish

This is perfect if you just want a bunch of fish swimmin around on your screen, especially if you want to feed them and customize a couple things with a pretty relaxed pace for an idle game. So that means I love it and it's exactly what I wanted, although if the developer reads this I do have one or two things that I think could maybe smooth out some of its rougher edges.

For instance, I initially assumed the "sell all unlocked" button meant unlocked as in I had discovered the name - not used the lock icon in the same menu to prevent selling (which makes sense in retrospect, but I hadn't paid attention to those icons before and this game doesn't explain it to you). This caused me to sell everything early on instead of clearing space for the fish that would actually count towards discoveries/progression, which was easy enough to recover from but a bit of a surprise. While I don't think this game necessarily needs the option to sell all discovered fish I do think it could be neat especially later on when painted/gold versions become the only new unlocks in a lower tier.

The only other thing I want to mention is that for an idle game it requires pretty much constant attention even with the "fewer clicks" mode due to the way the fish behave. Right clicking to start placing food without  maintaining mouse movement causes most of the smaller fish to orbit around the food and not actually eat much of it at all. This has led me to making constant small circular motions with the mouse in order to see any real progression even early on where the economy is usually a little more forgiving. This could very well be an intentional design decision, but to me it felt a little at odds with a design philosophy that already catered towards hand problems somewhat with the aforementioned fewer clicks mode (which I do really appreciate! I just found it a little ineffective when it came to reducing hand stress with the required constant motion).

With that being said I got this game on sale via (the) gnorp bundle and I think it's great! If what you see for the gameplay videos looks nice to you or simply enjoyable to have on a second monitor I really think you should get this (especially for only ~$5). My nitpicks are small and more quality of life grievances than anything and I'm really glad I took the chance to try this one out. Not for everyone maybe with the slower pace, but really enjoyable and peaceful while you slowly discover all the different fish.

This is an idle gotcha game that scratches that very specific collectors and lucky pack opening itch many of us get.

Buy fish, raise them, sell them for a profit; rinse and repeat until you've found every type of fish.

Game time progresses even with the game closed, so you don't have to keep the game open; however, it is neat to keep this open on a second screen as a sort of low-fidelity fish tank.
very glichy but fun
Blob blob

English: "I cannot recommend the game 'Chillquarium' at all. It is a frustrating and disappointing experience. The biggest problem is the save system, which is extremely flawed and completely ruins the gaming experience. No matter how much progress you make, there is always a constant risk of losing everything due to save errors. In addition, the multiple bugs present in the game make it practically impossible to fully enjoy it. Simple things like buying lights or taking care of fish become huge challenges due to programming errors.
It is evident that the developer did not take the time to do extensive testing before releasing the game to the market. It is inexcusable for a game to be released with so many technical problems. I paid a considerable price for this game and expected a quality experience, but what I got was a series of frustrations and disappointments.
While I initially loved the idea of the game and was excited to explore it, unfortunately my enthusiasm quickly faded when I encountered so many problems. I cannot recommend 'Chillquarium' to anyone in its current state. I sincerely hope that the developer will take the time to fix these issues and improve the user experience, but until that happens, it's best to avoid this game."

Español: "No puedo recomendar el juego 'Chillquarium' en absoluto. Es una experiencia frustrante y decepcionante. El problema más grande es el sistema de guardado, que es extremadamente defectuoso y arruina por completo la experiencia de juego. No importa cuánto progreso hagas, siempre hay un riesgo constante de perder todo debido a errores en el guardado. Además, los múltiples bugs presentes en el juego hacen que sea prácticamente imposible disfrutarlo plenamente. Cosas simples como comprar luces o cuidar de los peces se convierten en desafíos enormes debido a errores de programación.
Es evidente que el desarrollador no se tomó el tiempo necesario para realizar pruebas exhaustivas antes de lanzar el juego al mercado. Es inexcusable que un juego se lance con tantos problemas técnicos. Pagué un precio considerable por este juego y esperaba una experiencia de calidad, pero lo que obtuve fue una serie de frustraciones y decepciones.
Aunque inicialmente me encantó la idea del juego y estaba emocionado por explorarlo, lamentablemente mi entusiasmo se desvaneció rápidamente cuando me encontré con tantos problemas. No puedo recomendar 'Chillquarium' a nadie en su estado actual. Espero sinceramente que el desarrollador se tome el tiempo necesario para solucionar estos problemas y mejorar la experiencia del usuario, pero hasta que eso suceda, es mejor evitar este juego."

Pd: soy un español con el sueño de que arreglen el juego, porque lo adoro... Pero no creo que lo hagan...

Very easy game to drop in and out of.
You start with an empty aquarium that you buy packs for which give you 4 random fish, each fish gives a certain amount of money per (real-time) day.
Once you get enough money you can buy more aquariums and fill them with fish to increase your daily earnings even more.

With a recent update they added a "Less clicking" mode which helps you make your fish grow up faster without having to spam or autoclick, otherwise they will just grow up overtime (with some rare/mythical fish taking up to 7 days).

Only real downsides are the lack of music variety and because the fish packs are RNG you won't always get the ones you want & you'll have to grind a few packs to get the more rare ones to finish off your discovered species.

Very chill game overall and there are options to make the aquarium like a screensaver which is nice.

Easy to play, cute art and chill vibes. I love the variety of fish, including the occasional mollusc or crustacean. Some of the painted variants are gorgeous!
I also appreciate the accessibility feature of an auto clicker, it makes the game easier to play for people such as myself.

As far as future content goes, I do hope the dev does decide to keep going with Chillquarium, as I do think it has a lot of potential! I would love to see some more gameplay mechanics (different xp boosters, autoclickers outside of the accessibility option etc.), more decorations and more fish is always a given!

Either way, I love having this game on in the background while I do other things.

The game's core gameplay loop and all of its achievements have no respect for your time. You'll have to open thousands of packs to even begin to get the chance to earn the "golden" achievement, and you'll need to do so for each of the five categories of fish. It's not fun, it's not engaging, it's not relaxing, it's not challenging, it's just an absolute waste of time.

If you could buy better packs for each category that would significantly improve the chances, that might start to be reasonable, but would still probably just be a gigantic waste of time.

Something I would rlly like to see in the game tho is more decorations! And what would be even cooler (and what I'd like even more than just more decorations) is having the ability to have coral! It'd make the salt water tanks way prettier and more realistic (:

Enjoy watching fish swim back and forth? Want to avoid the hassle of maintaining a fish tank? Then this is the game for you! At the beginning, there are many of the same species of fish, such as bala sharks, that you would find in a starter aquarium. The fish look realistic and even display some realistic behaviors, such as staying in the appropriate swimming zone. There's a wide variety of both common and rare fish. Also, this game has a huge collection system which takes a LOT of time to complete. I highly recommend this game!

Definitely get this on sale unless you just...really like fish. If you watch the trailer, that's the entire game. I knew this going in and have been entertained and gotten my money's worth but it's not a very deep game at all. There's very little to do all things considered but the art, aesthetic and presentation is nice and opening packs of stuff is cool if you want that faux gambling dopamine hit. The achievements are an insane grind and will probably take you potentially 100+ hours to unlock since they're just RNG based and involve spending a ton of time opening thousands and thousands of packs of fish etc. If you just want to get this game to play and open every once in a while (it is an "idler" to a large degree and has background progress even when closed, although much of the game does also need direct input so it's a massive time sink as well), make some incremental progress and play it "casually" then you'll probably quite enjoy it. If you're going for "completion" this is going to be a huge huge time investment.

It's also a gacha game, but if you're actively searching for and playing gacha mechanics I suggest deleting steam, and going out and getting the help you need. With a strong social support network, I know you can become a better person and have some depth. I'm rooting for you.

This game is so wholesome and simple, but still makes you want to log in every day to check up on your tanks and roll for more fish. It's a gacha game for free. Free gacha. It's unheard of, but not in this game. Free. Fish. Gacha. No way to spend real money beyond the initial purchase of the game itself. You get to roll for rare and shiny fish, and they swim around in customisable tanks. I really recommend this game! My only recommendation to improve the game is a minor quality of life update, which is the ability to use the ESC key (or any hotkeys) to open up the menus... Sometimes I trap my fish in a corner being fed to grow faster, and it's a tad annoying to drag my mouse all around to open everything. But even without that change, it's such a lovely game, and I can't recommend it more for the price. I can't wait to try out other games by the developer.

Beat the game - bought all upgrades in the shop, and have about $2T in cash:

The game rules. It's a very, very light idle & loot crate sim. The fish are cool, the economy is pretty fun, there is tech for manipulating exp, etc. etc.

Overall, it's a very cool couple of active hours, plenty of passive hours, and you can go forever hunting shinies.

Personally I enjoy the chill of being able to just feed some fish and let them grow over time and also being able to keep certain fish around. I do wish that there were some info/stat buttons on the shop items though so I could see if there's anything different about the pebbles or tanks.

Give it a look if you want to check out a chill fish game for fairly cheap.

Was loving the game. Very relaxing and enjoyable idle game with no MTX. I would leave it running overnight on occasion. That was my downfall. Left it running overnight last night and when I came back home today my computer had frozen up, so I had to use the force restart button on my tower which essentially cycles the power. Come back to the game and I have all of the same aquariums. (Fresh 1, 2, and 3 + Salt 1) But I have ZERO saltwater fish, and all of the fish in my freshwater tanks are completely identical. I also had 0 money. I had been finally getting through the marine dwellers. I've now lost weeks worth of progress and, frankly, my interest in the game. Could it be an issue with my PC and not the game? Possibly. But it was the only program left running overnight and here I am today, fishless and penniless. 

TL;DR Would still recommend, just don't leave it running overnight

I'd recommend this game, but there's a few things the dev should change that would improve the quality of life the game has:

- make it so that the adult fish can't consume fish food so that you can prioritize growing your baby fish first.
- UI is clunky. Could/should use visual improvement, especially in the case when you're locking up your legendary fish for saving before bulk selling other fish. Not a huge fan of scrolling through upwards of 100 fish and double checking which fish are locked because the lock/unlock sign is the same white/blue color scheme with minor changes. Also, this is a minor point, but renaming the fish has no tangible effect on gameplay or the visuals, nor does it play some role in the filtering options for the lists, so I'm unsure why it's in this game.
- add more impactful decorations worth buying from the store beyond the draggable fish decoration PNGs and recolors for the fish light and aquarium ground. 
- maybe a bit more music tracks? I enjoy the current selection, but I feel as if it's so short that it feels repetitive.

I'm sure there's many features you can add to this game that could expand it beyond what it already offers and still have it feel like an idle experience. And I do hope that dev continues to update it with new gameplay ideas. If I could give it a numerical rating out of 10 for how well it succeeds as an idle game, I'd give it a 7 (closer to a 6).

Chillquarium is a fun little idle game. There are no microtransactions, and it is not very complicated, you mostly just open "booster packs" of fish and feed them, slowly unlocking better fish.

Most idle games out there try to milk their players with micro transactions, and this game does not. Big point in its favor. Most idle games don't really end, with an ever increasing grind that could take years to actually finish. This game does end after about 20 hours or so, maybe 40 if you do a lot of collecting. Small point in its favor.

Even though this game dodges some of the worst tendencies found in idle games, at the end of the day its just ok. Its not terribly engaging, and while it is kind of relaxing, its also not that much to look at. The idea is you have an aquarium of fish to look at while it idles, but the animations and fish designs really aren't that great. The cosmetic options are there and its better than bare bones, but only just. The gameplay is mostly figuring out how to make money efficiently with your fish, which I do enjoy, but its not quite intricate enough to be satisfying.

One thing I will praise is the pacing. Even though there are significant milestones, you reach them all in a fairly timely manner, especially with efficient play. Most idle games give you a few milestones every hour to start with which then slows to crawl with a milestones every few days or even weeks. This game stays consistent with giving you big upgrades every hour or two, basically up to the end. 

For me the bottom line is that I had a good time and it didn't overstay its welcome. A good idle game to mess around with while watching videos or even while playing other games. A good use for your second screen.

This game saved my life.

I am 37.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

I once bought this game about a fish tank. Said it was going to be a Wild and crazy time. The people came, the drinks were flowing and it was all the Rage. This game was not for me. I enjoyed the party but when it came to my fish, I wanted it to be as relaxed as possible. What could I possibly do..... Then out of the blue pops up, Chillquarium. Could it be? A relaxed fish tank game that is all about "taking it easy" enjoying yourself and having a good time. I was in disbelief. Thinking to myself, that last fish tank game was quite ruckus. I was not at all able to relax let alone, "Chill." Alas I was incorrect. This game was all that and more. Sitting here Setting up my Chillquarium has been nothing more than a relaxed, zenlike, calming experience. All jokes aside this game is really fun. You unlock fish and try and complete collections all while generating income and buying more fish packs.

I like this game kinda. Gameplay wise it's like a gacha game but without MTX, the fish packs you buy give you totally random fish and they can come in normal, painted, or golden variety, adding to the gambling element. You work your way up through the fish packs starting on the freshwater friends, only little tiny fish which do not make much money, to the more exotic fish, and all away to the giants which I haven't got to yet but I assume includes stuff like the ocean sunfish. It's a pretty decent progression system IMO at least so far for me, you don't have to play the game very actively though you can speed it up a little bit by feeding the fish which gives them XP to grow more.

I think what the game could do with though is a bit more content and depth. Right now it feels very barebones, there are a few things you can tinker around with and customise but not much. Though this game did only come out a few months ago so hopefully in the future the developers will add some more stuff.

Overall if you are a gacha game fan that likes to keep their money, or fan of idle games like me, then you can give this a go

After playing for over 100 hours, it is hard for me to recommend this game to people. The game has little to no features, and the gameplay loop is repetitive. There is so much missed opportunity in this game, it seriously feels like a cash grab. Compared to other idle games this game is remarkably barren of creativity. Every fish has the exact same idle animations and feeding animations. At the end of the day, this is a glorified $5 screensaver that you can click on. It is frustrating because the concept of the game is solid and the art style is fun. But when you look at the shop you realize just how little effort went into making this game. There are so many things that the developers could have added to this game, to name a few off the top of my head unique idle animations, unique feeding animations, a lot more ways to personalize and decorate your fishtanks, more packs than 5, more fish tanks, and the list goes on and on. This game will feed you more of the same with the only rewards being the rare golden and rainbow fish, which lack any special animations or character. It is disappointing that there is this much potential in a game that will never be brought to fruition because the dev already made his money selling this half baked game.

To make the short point long: This game is an idler w/gacha elements that *don't* cost you your wallet. As time passes, whether it's within hours or in days, you earn enough money to get the next batch of fish you'd like (which is the gacha element essentially, you buy 4 random fish in a pack), or upgrade the fish food, or buy that one decoration you think looks neat! It's very low-stakes since you're just filling in your fish collection and the decorations are, well, decorative, up to you to do something with. 

At first the pricetags of all the items look daunting, but I think they're mostly well balanced for the simplicity of this game. I'd recommend popping into it every once in awhile just to see what new fish have grown and what else you can do to complete collections! ...Unless you're like me, and like having the fish keep you company on your desk, and thus rack up many more hours than seems reasonable. You're valid then.

Idle games are stupid. Chillquarium is an idle game. Chillquarium is a stupid game.

But still it's one of the most fun Idle games I've ever played.

It's not as "addicting" and sometimes the pace is sub-optimal, but the relaxing atmosphere and pretty graphics make up for it.

You can buy sets of baby fish and wait until they grow up or manually feed them (by clicking). Once they grow up you can sell them or let them generate income. There are multiple "stages" e.g. fresh water and salt water and you can unlock better fish or additional tanks. Everything is very basic, but that makes it simpler and not as stressfull.

I'd give it a 3 out of 5 stars, which is good given the price. If you expect an spectecular, amazing game you will be disappointed. If you simply want to kill some time with a pretty idle game, then it's a good choice.

Great small game that has you checking in more than you realise. It's not a clicker game (well sorta it is but not like Cookie Clicker). You start off with a small tank and through buying random fish "decks" in gacha-style you collect rare fish that are worth more when grown.

Growing fish (maturing) takes real life time where the game can be closed and still 100% progressing the growth rate. I would advise "playing" this game more like a daily check-in type of experience where you get to see what progress was made during the day or when the game was closed.

At the start, fish don't bring in a lot of money/day but as you progress, numbers go up. With the money (profit) you get from selling your fish, you buy upgrades for your watertank, your fish food gives out more XP/bite and decorations for your tank.

Major plus for this game:
- Price in sale
- Progression of maturity of fish continues offline
- Cute graphics, perfect in windowed mode on a second monitor
- Amazing relaxing soundscape
- Accessibility options to have less clicks needed (for example: 1 click for food and food keeps coming automatically from the cursor point) 

Negatives:
- Not the depth of a cookie clicker experience
- there is no strategy, pure luck and hunting for achievements might take a while depending on the luck.

Enjoy it as a casual hop in hop out experience, ive been just coming back daily, slowly progressing. If you want continuous dopamine hits or continuous gameplay, this is not it. If you want a chill daily progression gacha-style game, this is it.

Also there is NO MTX or additional content. What you buy is what you get.

100 HOUR EDIT: I knew this would happen. In much the same way as Insaniquarium, this game has captivated me and ruled my life. Upon finding out that my favourite fish, the wahoo, was held within this game, I immediately had set my goal. I wanted one hundred of them. ONE HUNDRED wahoos, all to myself. All in one tank. See, for many years "wahoo" has been my exclamation of excitement. It's what I said when I was accepted to college, the single word I uttered as I lost my virginity, the word I uttered when I had finally broken free from my crippling Insaniquarium-induced fish-simulator addiction. Now that I have one hundred of my very own wahoos, they exclaim for me. I simply tab on when the word should be said, and they shout it one hundred times. My choir of voices, the armada of fish within Saltwater Tank 3, shall never be silenced or stifled. This game has awoken something evil within me, and I must continue to raise hell.
fish :)

This is a solid idol game where you move up in tiers of fish as you earn more money. By the end of the game, as it is now, you're raking in the trillions.

As an aquarium enthusiast, I was excited to see real fish and how they were represented as drawings. Each time you buy fish, you don't know which ones you're going to get, like a mystery box. I liked collecting them all. I also enjoyed the progression from guppy to giant squid and all the interesting things in between.
It was worth the price I paid for it. 

Some criticisms: The fish from the 'giant' category, which is the last tier, aren't all that big. I was disappointed by that after being excited for them through all the other tiers, but it wasn't a game-breaker. And while the UI is generally pretty thoughtful, there are still a few improvements that could be made in my opinion. Additionally, the game allows you to change the color of the light in each aquarium, which is awesome, but it changes the way that looks at night [in real time], and I wish there was a way to turn that functionality off.

Other than a few nit-picky changes like those, it's an awesome game, especially for one coming from one person!

WOW.

I wanted a laid back point and click game to have on the side while I'm playing my other main game (Satisfactory).

I thought I'd be playing for 30 minutes but I played for 12 hours yesterday.  Very simple and so far it's been fun collecting every fish.

Only gripe I have is with the drop rate for gold/painted legendary and mythic fish which I'll bet will take a thousand hours, so I only plan on collecting my base "pokedex" of fish.

Other than that, totally worth the money.  Just one tip, use the "fewer clicks option" so that you don't get carpel tunnel.  BUT remember to turn it off before opening up your packs of fish so you can open them one by one and enjoy discovering your new fish!  Once you've unlocked all of them for a certain set, you can def go back to fewer clicks while opening them. 

Have fun!

This game single-handedly curbed my impulsive buying tendencies. My gambling problem quakes before this gatcha game for 2D pixel fish. 

Premise: Keep buying till you get the fish you want (no actual human dollars involved). 

Features: Mindlessly click a singular button and watch your fish army swarm your mouse for a chance to eat. I think I dissociated just staring at my screen and thinking "me irl" every time a clownfish swam by.

I think about this fish game all the time. I keep thinking "man today's been rough, I can't wait to go home to play my dumb little fish game". It's so uncomplicated, it's just shapes and colours (and capitalism) and I couldn't ask for anything more harmless to hyperfixate on. 

Therapy? Expensive. Fish gatcha? 8$ during the Steam Sale.
what a chill game, hopefully it continues development. keep it up!

As a long-time fan of Insaneaquarium- back when it was a browser game in the early years of PopCap, I was immediately interested in the idea of an aquarium-themed idle game. It reminded me of the Screensaver game mode from the CD version of Insaneaquarium. As a result, it is difficult for me to play this game without directly comparing it with its "competition."

I really love the variety in the fish as well as the possibility to get rare fish. As far as the amount of unique fish models and colors go, the game offers a lot.

However, I would really like to see an improvement on the art style of the game, as all the assets look like artificially upscaled pixel art. I think it would look more charming as pixel art, and the developer could perhaps spend some time making the props, decorations, and background art look more sophisticated by improving the lighting/light source, studying more about making a pleasing palette for background art, etc. As of now, it appears a little "gloopy" due to (I assume) to be the upscaling situation. I recall looking at the background props and finding the art to look kind of smudged or like some colors were unintentionally or not confidently placed.  

Secondly, I feel like the game offers a great deal of content for its price, but it could stand to have a few more gameplay elements. It could perhaps introduce more "milestones" such as giving small rewards for "sell 10 fish, sell 20 fish, sell 50 fish, etc." It could also take some inspiration from its competition by adding in "useful" decorations or permanent resident fish that proc their abilities at well-paced intervals: fish that give birth to more fish, or a tank upgrade that automatically feeds your fish, were some ideas that came to mind. I'd also like to see a built-in screensaver mode.

Additionally, some quality-of-life improvements: I recommend an option to sort fish by the amount of experience they need to become full grown. Sometimes I like to try to "prioritize" feeding the ones that are closest to growing. It'd be easier to find them if I could sort by experience. (If I can already do this, I overlooked it!)

 I think the game is very charming and well-priced on its own, and I always enjoy supporting indie devs. My suggestions are just ideas, they may or may not vibe with your vision.

Game is a total blast. Simple, addicting, and cheap. I keep it on throughout the day while working. Pop in between tasks to feed some fish and zone out. GOTY so far.

My initial thoughts (I've only just bought my first saltwater tank and started getting the reef fish)
- The game is very calming, watching your fish swim around is neat and the color variations (painted, golden, etc.) are attractive to look at which makes them fun to collect
- The early game is VERY slow- I ended up taking advantage of an exploit to make it go along faster. However it seems once you hit river and reef fish it speeds up considerably. Still, I feel like the smallest fish should make you more money as right now even the rarest small fish don't make more than common/rare river fish so there's no reason to keep any of them beyond aesthetics. Also the mythic (highest rarity) small fish is kind of a joke in terms of earning power
- The number of tanks you get seems limiting- there's only 3 freshwater and 3 saltwater tanks. I wanted to make one or two aesthetic tanks, a golden fish tank, and a rainbow fish tank (maybe) for both salt and freshwater fish, but since you only get 3 of each and one of them will almost always be your "meta" money earning tank I'll probably have to cut something.
- It would be nice if the fish had a bit more personality, like maybe special interactions between certain species of fish or with decorations. The designs are attractive but at the moment they just feel like floating pngs.
- The number of decorations seems slightly limited, and it would be nice if you could recolor them.

Given that the game only came out late last year (so a couple of months ago at the time of writing) the fact that it's a bit barebones is understandable, and the dev seems hard at work adding new features. The game itself is also fun. Still though, part of me thinks that this should have been labeled as an early access game...

Looking forward to seeing the new features as the dev adds stuff!

It is what it is, a laid-back aquarium game that leans more towards being an "Idler" game, where you check in for a few seconds every day. In this aspect, it performs well.

However, being aware that the game is from an independent indie developer, there are some oversights and issues that I'd like to see addressed. Primarily, the game seems restricted to the standard 16:9 aspect ratio. Allowing for 21:9, 16:10, etc., is crucial for any modern game.

Then the ability to purchase the "Salt Water" tank is available long before you can actually afford to buy any fish for that tank. Some balancing is needed here, or perhaps when acquiring a new tank, including some "free fish" as a starter kit, similar to what you'd get at an actual pet store, could be beneficial.

Moving on to the cosmetic upgrades, they are quite expensive. While this might be acceptable if they were reusable, once placed, your only option is to delete them. Being unable to put items into storage for reuse or move decorations between tanks feels like a basic feature that should be implemented.

Lastly, the game itself could use a cosmetic refresh. While it does have its own style, it reminds me of a Windows 98 fish wallpaper. It's possible that this is intentional on the developer's part, and I'm not expecting the latest RTX graphics, but aiming for something a bit more timeless might be a worthwhile pursuit. In reality this is another game I'd prefer to rate as "neutral" - but it's definitely not deserving of a negative review as it still offers exactly what it promises to you.

There is a huge cost gap between fish from different card pack.
e.g. You will earn 20$ each raised fish from the starter pack. But after you can buy the next pack that cost 1000$. You immediately will get 500$ if you raised and sold the 1000$ pack fish.
So there are no reasons for player to keep buying those cheap fish pack because they can't really get more profit out of it.
Meanwhile, fish from the more expensive fish pack may not be your type of fish. You get them just so sell them. It makes the game kinda grindy and the chill part is out.
The progression is based on when you can earn enough and buy the next more expensive fish card pack. It is very predictable after a few hour into the game (After you understand the economy of it)

While I love this game, I cannot say that I'd be able to recommend it in its current state. It feels a bit unbalanced, as upgrades are unsubstantial but very expensive, deterring you from active gameplay in preference of a much more hands-off real time aquarium sim. I can see the vision, and I respect that some players may prefer a more 'realistic' aquarium simulation, but from the approach of it being an incremental/'idler' game I think the option between a "realistic" difficulty and a "casual" difficulty would be welcome. 

Decor items also feel needlessly expensive to the point where they go from *decor* items to a weird form of money sink side-progression that ultimately leads to nowhere and distracts you from the actual core gameplay loop of saving up enough money to purchase the next fish packet. I think all decor items should either be relatively cheap, *or* provide some sort of gameplay incentive, e.g happier fish produce more money and mature faster. 

Despite all that I've sunk countless hours into this game, and its brought me a lot of respite through some harsh times. If it's on sale, it's worth picking up. I'm excited to see where this game heads in the future!

I feel that the game, in its current state, may not justify its price tag. I've experienced other idle games that offer richer content at no cost and without the issues associated with pay-to-win models.

What a cute game!

On its surface it's a very simple game, but when you get into it you find...it's a very simple game!

It has absolutely no draining, straining or frustrating elements - except for manic completionists who need to find all the fish and find them SOON. They NEED it! (They kinda includes me, but never mind).

The fish grow at specified time levels. Common can grow relatively swiftly and legendary and mythic need you to get on with your life and come back later or even a couple of days later. You can speed up the process by feeding the fish, but the game is not meant for speed. It's a screen saver with gameplay elements. And it's great.

I'm not sure how I feel about the "real time" aspect of the game (the fish continue to grow even with the game shut off). On one hand, it removes the fun of hearing them (yes, they make a little "pop" sound when they mature) grow up. On the other, some of those higher level fish have seemingly impossible growth spans. I'm gonna side with it's okay and just remember to load up the tank before going to sleep each day.

I do wish there was a little more in-game (simple) functionality. There is no in-game "help" and though the game is simple and intuitive, it would be nice to have some tips or explanations. I couldn't tell if the "earns $x.xx per day" actually earned you money or if you needed to just sell the fish. Staring at the screen for a while finally showed a penny being added, so I got my answer.

Some keyboard shortcuts would also be nice. The developer added a "less clicks" choice to help out the mouse impaired (or injured), so to top it off, a key binding to pull up the fish tank, fish list and store would be cool.

BUT!!!!

This game is already cool. And, like the title says, chill. Get it now. Reward this developer for such a nice concept and then reward yourself with a cute and peaceful little game!

Need I elaborate further?
Simple and easy to understand. Collection is fun and straightforward, and Progression is not frustrating. Love discovering all the variations as well!

Overall, highly recommend.  Chill, relaxing, stress-free.  You buy eggs.  You hatch eggs.  You force feed your little fry or just let them grow-up in time.  You sell them to buy more eggs, or patiently wait for enough coins from their idle income.  You start getting variants.  Painted, golden, RAINBOW!  You find more tiers!  Rare, epic, legendary, MYTHIC!  You can't decide what you should spend money on first...a new tank, a new type of fish or a mossball? You watch your coins per day income tick slowly upward.  $100, $1000, $1,000,000!  You get ridiculously excited over some cute little creature (I'm looking at you, rainbow axolotl).
You can play low speed as a full idle, or you can play it a little faster by clicking to feed your fish.  Either way, it is a pleasant way to discover the fluidity of time as somehow, mysteriously, your minutes turned into hours and you just need a few more coins to buy more eggs...again.
A couple things I liked:
1. Progress from the demo carried over into the full game.  There is a data reset option, and I did use it, but having that choice was nice.
2. Artwork.  It is simple, but it works well with the vibe of the game.
3. Buy all and sell all options.  This can speed things up and save some of the clicking if you are a grinder.
4. Light colors.  It was nice to be able to get different colors of lights and gravel to reduce eyestrain.
5. You can name your fish.

Didn't like:
1. Experienced a bug where my fish would vanish sometimes.  When I only had one tank, I had to close and re-open the game to get them back.  It would show them in my list of fish, but not let me feed them or see them.  Once I had additional tanks, I could just switch between tanks and they would reappear.
2. Decorations can only be moved on the horizontal plane they start off on.  No options for foreground or background.

QOL features I'd like to see added:
1. An income counter for the total of all tanks, not just the tank you are currently viewing.
2. An option to disable the automatic night light.  Yes, you can manually turn the lights on each time, but it defaults back to automatic.
3. Update the fish checklist to show all painted variants.  Maybe as a drop down from the current thumbnails.  I'm not a raving completionist, but it would be nice to know if I have completed a collection.

You have a marvelous game on your hands here, Ben Reber.  Thank you for the demo version.  It made the decision for me to treat myself to the full game for Christmas.

Edit for Update 1.1 - 
Dev listened and removed SOME of the tedium. My issue with the selling is still present, and not all of the tedium of mechanics has been removed - but buying and opening packs is much more doable, Take this review as "get it if you're patient and not super into achievement hunting" now. 
---

There's nothing chill about this game, nor fun, either. 

For a while, I enjoyed this game, even before the hotfix that actually made it manageable without an autoclicker, but the longer I played it, the more issues I realised it has, especially in regards to achievement hunting. 

It's tedious and grindy, like not even voodoo garden involved grind where the harder you work, the more progress you make. This will take dozens of hours, even with a min-max auto-clicker in the bottom of your screen. It's the boring grind that steals your mouse hostage and leaves you looking at your phone because you can't use your PC, because playing any other way will take you at least triple the amount of time. Because, oh my gosh, is this game slow paced. 

The unlockables, tanks and fish tiers take forever, and not in a satisfying way, because you're not doing anything. You're just waiting for it to say you can get the next thing, and whilst this can be fun at first having something to aim for - when you get to the last tier of fish, it becomes idle-game levels of "oh my god how long do I have to wait to unlock this". 

And when it isn't an idle game? The controls and UI are horrifically optimised. You want to see all your adult fish in the tank in the tab you're in? Jokes on you, you have to cycle through every tab to "refresh" the adult fish tab because it doesn't count any new ones since you last pressed the tab. You want to fill a 100-fish tank? Get ready to press that "buy 4 fish" 25 times, and then press the card packs 25 times to unlock the fish, then press every fish. Then do that for all 6 of your 100-fish tanks. Every 8 hours. Do you know how clunky and poorly optimised this game is? Someone described this as a good game to play when you're stoned on your second monitor - and you'd need to be to have the patience for it.

^ And if you want achievements? If you want golden fish or rainbow fish? Do that entire process repeatedly, selling all your baby fish (that need to be refreshed in the tab every time!) getting 0.05% odds on hopefully pulling one of the hundreds of fish you need. You can be sat here opening fish packs for hours. It's tedium incarnate. 

It's not fun, it's poorly made, and I miss those 41 hours of my life.

[h1]Peaceful Aquarium Game[/h1]


[i]Chillquarium[/i] is a lovely little idle game of raising fish in a series of aquariums.  It's not much more than that, really, but it's pretty.

You start out buying packs of fish.  Each pack contains four fishies, but it's a random draw within that pack's group, out of sixteen species in each of five groups  There are common, rare, epic, and legendary species within each group.

Each species has normal, painted, and golden varieties, with painted and golden worth more than normal.

There is a small idle component to the game.  Fishies start out as small baby fish and take a few minutes to about a week to grow up.  You can right-click to drop a bit of fish food to help them grow up a bit faster.  Once grown, fishies earn money.

You can also sell off fish for money.  Selling baby fish gets you a few cents each, but selling most adult fish easily gets much more than the price of an entire pack.  You can select individual fishies and lock them so you can't easily sell them, especially with the "sell all" button.

A listing of the fish in a tank can be sorted by various categories, including income and value.  You can rename individual fishies, but neither name nor species are sorting categories.

Max capacity of a tank is 100 fish, which makes it complicated and tricky to select a fish swimming about.  Fortunately, you can also select fish in the tank's list.


Accumulating money allows you to buy the more expensive packs, upgrade tank capacity, add decorations, or purchase new tanks.  You can have three freshwater tanks, and three saltwater tanks.

Decor is sadly limited, just large tank ornaments such as a castle or boulder, several colors of sand for the bottom, and several colors of lighting.

The only impactful upgrade beside new tanks and tank capacity is one that increases the fish growth XP of the fish food.

The game is soothing to watch.  Fishies are bright and colorful cartoon versions of various real species, including classics like goldfish, koi, bettas, and clownfish, as well as deeper sea fish like viperfish and bottomfeeding flounder.  A snail or two can also be found.

There's a HUD-free "Chill" mode to watch the fishies swim about.  However, it quickly turns visually "busy" as the fish pile up.

The fish behavior AI is simple but good.  Bottomfeeder types tend to stay to the bottom, snails stay on the aquarium floor, and fish species tend to school together.

The soundtrack has soothing guitar tunes.  In a nice touch, an air filter sound runs in the background for added realism.  


[i]Chillquarium[/i] is basically what the title implies, a "chill" little aquarium game you can hang out with and watch or check in just once a day.  While there's not much more to it than collecting your fishies, you can make up your own game modes.

I built up my tanks while keeping one of each species and species variant.  You can go faster if you aim to keep as many high-value fish as you can, or just keep selling off every fish until you have every tank unlocked at their highest capacity, and then aim for some final goal of fish collection.

-For the price I feel that I am not really getting a lot of playtime here.  There isn't really much going on besides buying something and waiting.  There are gold sink systems but none of them are rewarding in the sense of progression.  It just all feels like a waste.  

-You get a tank and buy some fish.  Each fish has some sort of passive income to the tank and gives a large lump sum if sold.  

-You can buy more fish and upgrades to sorted things that increase your ability to buy a larger tank or better fish and that's the end of the upgrade systems.  The rest you waste gold on very few lights and decorations that are simply only there to waste money on.   

-The game has a good selection of fish perhaps 150 or so that you can unlock.  The game will run out of content somewhat quickly, perhaps 30 to 40 hours of content to 100% the game is what I assume.  Maybe a bit quicker.  Assuming you can stand sitting around for that long.

-For the cost of this game the content is lacking for an idle game I feel.

-I wouldn't expect much more to be done based on the update frequency and the radio silence from the developer.  The game needs a lot of additions to provide a smoother, more involved experience for the player.  It feels slow, choppy, unbalanced and quite bland at the moment.

The graphics are cute and the game is straightforward. 
You buy fish through card packs of baby random fish (a gacha system). 
You overfeed your fish because they are never satisfied. 
You wait for them to grow up (either through feeding them for xp, or waiting for real time to pass), then you sell fish to buy more. Sometimes you have to determine if the long term idle money the fish will bring in will be worth more than the short term gain from selling them outright.
Sometimes the fish come in unique colors, or gold, and there is a list in game to show you what kinds of fish you've unlocked.

If you enjoy idle games and collecting, it's worth a try. It's no where near as engaging as something like Insaniquarium (if you're looking at it and expecting them to be similar) but it doesn't take a lot to run so it genuinely can just be a cute and interactive desktop/screensaver sort of scenario. If you're expecting something more in depth, this isn't that kind of game.

i like chillquarium a lot and think it is a very stress relieving game. Anyone who struggles with stress would probably love it for two reasons: 1. it is a very slow going game so you could leave it on overnight and not make a whole of progress. 2. there is no quests so you can just mess around and see what you can do.

I love it! I'm very compelled to get all the gold fish, feels very achievable over time. Very nice thing to have open in the background and check in on whenever I need some form of stimulation. It stops me from checking social media all the time which is nice. I also love the art direction of the fish, they're very cute.

Some things I think would improve the game: 

Adding tank names - I often get confused which tank I'm looking at unless I use decorations. It would be nice to have the ability to name them yourself or something other than a number to differentiate them. Also a back button to clear the name headings from the top right after accidentally fat fingering the swap tanks button.

Having a statistic that will calculate how much money per second or per minute you are making - The counter goes very quickly and it would be a nice QOL update to be able to calculate the rate of money you can afford to splurge on the giant packs at a chance for golds or rainbows at a given time. 

Those are my two big wants which I think would make the most sense and wouldn't be too hard to include in a clicker style game. If anything to resolve that already exists then disregard. Overall, as a fish lover its a very nice game to run in the background while I do tasks :)

I've played many idles games and I would argue this one has by far the least amount of things you can do.
Lets go over what you can do in this game:
You can buy fish out of 5 sets. 2 for freshwater and 3 for salt water.
If you push right click you can directly feed the fish to make em grow faster. You can sell fish for money or keep em alive to gain money over time.
You can upgrade your tank to hold more fish or buy additional fishtanks. Upgrading allows them to hold more fish.
You can buy decorations that serve no purpose other than cluttering up the screen. The fish do not interact with them in anyway.
You can buy new sand types for the floor. But it has no gameplay impact.
You can buy new colored lights but again, no gameplay impact.

And that's it. This is honestly barely a game. You'd be much better off playing nearly any other idler.

[b][u]This game was reviewed using Version 1.0.4. Your experience on other versions may vary.[/u][/b]

[h3][b][u]Short Answer:[/u][/b][/h3] An idle game that definitely accomplishes its goal of being cozy and relaxing, but it's one that I can only recommend provided you understand what you're getting into first. In truth, it's closer to an interactive screensaver than a traditional idle game, with progression (i.e. collecting the 100+ unique fish species) that's purely dependent on luck and no real metagame to speak of. Though I still enjoyed it, players that want a more hands-on experience may want to look elsewhere.

[h3][b][u]Long Answer:[/u][/b][/h3] [i]Chillquarium[/i] is an idle game about buying, raising, and selling all manner of fish big and small in your own personal aquarium. You'll start with common pet store finds like goldfish and bettas, using the funds from their sales to purchase larger wild-caught species like panfish, carp, and trout. Eventually, you'll migrate to saltwater fish with the same progression towards bigger and bigger species, pushing the limits of what can reasonably be called an "aquarium fish" until you're suddenly sitting on a tank that's inexplicably filled with dozens of deep sea fish and several types of shark. Silliness aside, it's a more relaxed game that it might sound, sometimes to its own detriment.

Buying fish in this game is kind of like buying trading cards: there are five themed sets (e.g. small river fish, tropical reef fish) with 25 different species in each; and you can buy them in packs that give you four random fish from the set you chose. They start out as babies and need to grow into adults before selling them will turn a profit, and the growth period for each baby fish can last anywhere from five minutes to an entire week in real-time depending on the species. You can either ride out the timer (which still ticks down when the game is off, thankfully) or speed things up by feeding them food pellets, which increases their growth meter by a few points per pellet and can be continuously dropped into a tank for as long as you're willing to hold down the mouse button. Once a fish is fully grown, you can sell it off for significantly more than what you paid for it, allowing you to purchase more expensive fish packs, new tanks to increase your space, better fish food to increase the growth gain per pellet, and a wide variety of cosmetics to decorate your tanks.

Beyond that, there's a collection aspect to the game that you can pursue, which is the only actual goal [i]Chillquarium[/i] will gently push you to work towards. There are 125 unique fish to find as of writing, with separate achievements for netting all 25 species from each of the 5 sets. In true trading card-like fashion, every fish also has an uncommon painted (alternate color) variant and a rare golden variant that can sometimes appear in a pack, both of which are tied to separate achievements for their collection. If you're the completionist type, be warned that [b]how fast you can find new species and earn achievements is entirely based on luck[/b] since they can only be found in these random bundles—there's no metagame or strategy involved, and there are no shortcuts that don't involve manipulating your save file.

And...that's about it, really. Sure, the fish variety goes up along with the size of your bank account over time, but the gameplay itself never evolves—what you're doing for the first 20 minutes is exactly what you'll be doing in the next 20 hours. [b]It's very hands-off even for an idler, and it almost feels more like a customizable screensaver than a video game at times.[/b] Heck, there's even a "Chill Mode" to drive the point home, which hides the UI so you can put the game in full screen and pretend you've still got that aquarium screensaver that used to come with older versions of Windows. As a side note, if you do plan on leaving the game running for extended periods of time, I strongly recommend turning on the newly-added "Sparse Music" option in the settings as soon as you can. It's not because the music is bad or anything—quite the opposite, actually—it's because there's only a handful of short tracks in the game, and they get repetitive very quickly when they're all playing in a loop one after the other without a break.

On one hand, I tend to prefer more interaction with my idlers, with mechanics that let me influence and optimize my progression instead of just sitting around and hoping luck is on my side today. On the other hand, it's not like it's trying to tout itself as something more than it is—it markets itself as a "cozy and relaxing" idle game, and I'd say it accomplishes that goal just fine. Besides, it's managed to keep me checking in semi-regularly for the past three months, long enough for me to find all 125 fish; though whether I stick around to finish collecting their painted and golden variants is anyone's guess. [b][u]Overall, I'd give [i]Chillquarium[/i] a tentative recommendation: if you want something you can throw onto a second monitor to help you vibe while you work, then this will definitely get the job done; but if you want an idler you can more actively engage with, you're better off looking somewhere else.[/u][/b]

Fun and engaging creature collector! It's a well polished game, I haven't encountered any bugs. The artwork is fun and engaging, and for whatever reason, I keep wanting to play. Incredible work by the dev.

However, the game's progression feels repetitive at times. Some ideas occurred to me while I was playing, but I recognize my vision for the game and the dev's vision are likely quite different. Many people enjoy a slower pace of game, so take everything I say with a pinch of salt. (!!Minor game spoilers ahead!!) 

With that being said, I'd love more substantial upgrades that increase the pace of the game. While the new food upgrades are helpful, they are only minimally so, and do not change the pace of the game significantly, especially toward the late game. A larger diversity of upgrades would add more uses for money, rather than just fish and tanks. For example, a mid-game built in auto-feed mechanic rather than the user tabbing out while holding right click would feel rewarding after manually feeding fish for so long. The passive rate of fish XP essentially become negligible at a certain point, a one-time upgrade to decrease waiting time could be hugely helpful. Some form of quest system that rewards the player for collecting a wide variety of fish would incentivize discovering lower-value fish and buying lower-price packs. The artwork for the game is charming and engaging, and I love when there is more to the encyclopedias in these types of games, such as descriptions or fun facts, but I recognize I'm well in the minority. Finding a balance between too simple and too complicated is tough, and I think it's best to stay on the simpler side, so the game is in a fairly good spot right now. Overall, it is very well-crafted, but I'd love some small additions to give it more life.

Chillquarium can be explained 100% with its name. It is a chill aquarium game and I love it for being that.

As far as gameplay goes it is very minimal. Buy fish, feed them to make them grow up, get money, buy more fish, get more money, upgrade stuff, rinse and repeat. What helps with this even more is that fish grow and gain you money even when the game is off, so really you only need to put a few minutes into every day if you are not just trying to get everything as fast as possible. If you are really into it as well there are options to customize your fish tanks as well. Beyond that, there really is not much to this game, but there does not need to be. There is something very Zen about raising fish and decorating the tank, and I am all here for it. Nonetheless, I think that there are some changes that I would like to see. More tank customization would be the first thing I would add for sure though, there just isn’t enough. Hell even if they made it a 99¢ DLC I think that would be fair, much more than that though and they would be pushing it. I also think that there needs to be a way to more effectively fill your tank with fish when you are farming out collecting the fish, and the option to buy the maximum fish allowed would save me a bunch of time and save my mouse from 1000 unnecessary clicks. I also think that there should be a purchase that would increase your odds of getting painted or golden fish. If you put it late enough then you really aren’t harming the game either, you do not need to try to keep me as long as possible, I bought the game, don’t make me gamble 8000 times just to get golden fish, it is tedious and actually harms the game in my opinion. In all fairness though, even without those quality-of-life additions I think that the game is just fine, I do not need to min-max fish purchases, but for an achievement hunter like me, I do not appreciate how luck-based it is to get these achievements in a reasonably timed manner, but it is not like this game is hardcore or anything, so I digress.

As far as sound design goes it is completely serviceable, but it is limited. Gurgles and drops are about all you will hear beyond the background music. Speaking of the background music it is okay, it is peaceful enough that it fits in, but it does not really excel in any way.

Graphically I think the game is very well done. The pixel art is really solid, and I am always a sucker for that style. What makes it sit above and beyond many other games though is the lighting. The tank lighting can be customized and the way that it changes the look of the game is very appealing, hell I wish there were more of them, I think it is the strongest thing you can customize in the game. Overall, I think the pixel art was a good choice and the lighting excels.

So yeah, Chillquarium is a chill game and is something that I have just been casually putting time into on the side. I think that $6 is very fair if this type of game is something you are interested in, if you are looking for something more active though, I think you will feel a bit cheated. It is not a masterpiece by any means, but it does not need to be. Chillquarium intends to be a chill aquarium game, and it absolutely nails it.

This is a cute and chill little game. However, in all honesty I cannot recommend it as it is TOO chill - it's hardly a game at all. 
There's nothing to do, no reward for active play, no reason to keep the game open, basically no upgrades, no quests aside from the tutorial, and no story. 
You can feed your fish to make them grow faster, but the EXP this gives the fish is so minuscule it's not worth it. Also, the adult fish (which can't grow any more and just give passive income) mob your cursor for the food only baby fish can eat. 
As a simulation/desktop tank it's not great either. The fish swim around, but they don't seem to have different behaviours besides the snails, which are slow and stay on the bottom. The decorations are also very expensive so you won't be able to do any customisation for weeks of real time. There's also not many decorations, so you'll be looking at the same thing for a long time.

It's great for what it is: a very uninvolved idle fish overfeeding simulator. It's not really a 'game' beyond some very barebones mechanics of buying 'card packs' of fish and then watching your income go up by virtue of fish somehow generating.... income? It all is very silly and makes basically zero sense but at the same time adds some goals to faff about with.

I'd love if there was more to the game, but at the same time I think this minimalist stuff is what the game was also meant to be, so again, it's 'fine for what it is'.

I recommend it with the caveat that you go in knowing it's little more than an engaging screensaver.

Probably the politest fish I've ever seen; they'll never attempt to eat or fight each other (despite cramming up to 100 in a single tank), and they'll never starve or beg for food (unless of course, you insist on feeding them to mature them quickly and sell them for profit, which you'll probably want to do anyway).

Anyways, I've been checking in almost every single morning (since getting the game), and it's satisfying watching that in-game currency roll in, and faster so. Buy fish, sell fish once grown to full size (or keep them so that they generate money over time), buy cosmetics and more/better fish, rinse and repeat.

Once I've purchased all cosmetics (lights, pebbles and decorations) and seen all fish, I'll give this game a wrap (so no 100% achievements for me) since by then it's probably overstayed its welcome. Regardless though, it's a cute idler to invest your 'minutes a day' into. Give the demo a try if you like (progress carries over to the full game).

I bought this game because I love idler games and this one has a lot of positive reviews and isn't too pricey.

Perhaps I just don't "get it", but this game is incredibly boring. You hold down the right mouse button to feed fish and wait for a fish to grow into an adult fish, then sell the adult fish for money to buy more fish. And...that's it.

I guess later on you can buy different kinds of fish and decorate your tank a bit, but there should be some actual game play, otherwise this is just a virtual fish tank decorating game.

So basically the game play consists of holding down the right mouse button.

I know idler games typically don't have too much game play, but even by idler standards this is just very lacking. No story, no mechanics like buying something to help you feed the fish, no busywork side tasks like cleaning the fish tank or anything, no hunger meters for the fish to keep track of. You literally just hold the right mouse button and watch all of the fish swarm the food pellets like a bunch of piranhas that haven't eaten in three days.
Feeding those fish make me happy!

Really enjoying this! I played the demo a ton when it first launched, and the move to the full version from the demo is practically seamless, so i recommend downloading the demo first if you're on the fence. 
The different unlocks always feel really satisfying once you get them, and you really can just get absorbed in watching them all swim about. They recently also made it so the little fish move faster, so getting them to grow with the fish food is much easier now if you want to play actively. The sprites all look really nice, cool mix and style of smoothed out pixel art.

If i could say any complaint, it'd probably just be that once you unlock the newer fish for a tank, its not really profitable or worth it buying the older ones. Having a system where you could buff how much the older fish get you after you get far enough would be nice to increase tank variety. The numbers can get a bit disorienting once they get high enough also, i spent multiple days thinking i hit a wall, not realizing i just got the money number mixed up. Having a way to simplify the numbers once they get high enough would be helpful.

time turned to drips of water.
i finally got the gold i so searched for, but what was it all for.
achievements and empty platitudes, no more, no less.
water is deep. I rest easy now.

Always been a big fan of idle games due to not needing your full attention for long periods of time. Perfect to have on a second screen or in the background whilst putting your attention to something else. This one is particularly chilled, hence the name and is just like having a virtual fish tank. This is generally a positive review but with some cautionary comments. I 'completed' this game in 26.5 hours. What I consider completion is buying everything available to buy. It does not include getting all achievements, more on that shortly.
The game is fun whilst you have targets to aim for, such as increasing your daily income, getting the next tank or increasing your tank size, but it lacks depth after that. I also don't see any replay value, I've uninstalled it now and I don't expect to return to it unless there are more stages added, more fish etc... There's nothing else I can do, no other way to play it.

[b]What are the achievements I have left?[/b] 
I completed 7/15 achievements, the rest of the achievements are much the same, buy fish, hope you get a painted or gold, sell, repeat. There isn't anything there to keep me interested.

[b]So why positive?[/b] 
Because it is fun for 26.5 hours, seeing your daily profits grow, see each new fish come in and the benefit that it brings in terms of revenue. I remember thinking that I was bringing in 100k a day and how pleased I was, if I load up the game now, I'm bringing in something like 17 trillion a day. There is a real sense of progression for a short time.

Now that being said, if DLC was released, I [b]wouldn't[/b] buy it. I don't think there's enough content in the game yet to warrant issuing a DLC. It would feel a bit cheap, but that's for each person to decide.

So yes, it's a positive review overall because of the price, do I have my monies worth? Yeah, I think so, it certainly wasn't expensive. It just seemed really quick. There were times I left the game running in the background accidentally so it could probably be completed in much less time.

In summary, if you have £5 to spare and want something to check out, it's worth it. Just don't expect to sink a  lot of time into it.

Chillquarium is an idle aquarium sim that's low on fish care and high on aesthetics. It's a genuinely charming little game with a few flaws that keep it from being perfect, but, largely, for what it is, it doesn't need to be.

Starting with the cons...
- There are only enough tanks to store one of each fish. For collectors, they'll have to sell some fish they might rather keep to make room for rarer ones, and even then there probably won't be space enough left for your dream tank. It would be simple enough to add another fresh and salt tank in the future, or even make it so you can store one of each kind and color of fish. 
- There is currently only one music track, though this honestly isn't a huge issue. The music is nice, and the default setting has it come in and out over time, so it shouldn't get irritating too quickly. 
- Progression tends to feel a little weird. This might be fixed by now but sometimes getting a new set of fish doesn't really spring you forward like you'd think you would and in one instance I almost felt like I skipped one.
- The odds on some of the drops are kind of horrible? I got stuck trying to get the gold discus for about a week and then mopped up the other golds in three days, only having trouble getting the painted giants. I feel like a pity system that puts a little lean on getting unobtained fish would be a really good idea. 
- There's a bit of a lack of decor atm, though I think this will change in the future so won't comment on it much. Instead I'll suggest skull decor. Or how about a no fishing sign? More plants?

That's about all I can think of for negatives, now for the positives. 
- The art is very cute, and the entire thing is incredibly aesthetic. For idlers, the bubbling and adjustable light settings are great. This is basically a gachapon screensaver maker and due to a lack of in game purchases that's a good thing.
- The game is very inexpensive, with a modest six dollar asking price.
- The mechanic of obtaining and selling fish can definitely be rewarding, and the fish move like they ought to in life which is nice, with halibut and flounder dwelling on the bottom and tetras schooling.
- There is generally a good selection of lights and soil colors, letting you go for whatever kind of aesthetic you'd like, from understated to gaudy. 
- Your fish don't require any care, so you don't have to worry about making sure they don't die. For a game like this, that's a good thing. 

That's about all I have for positives, but, in a way, that's all this game needs. It's not perfect, and I hazard to call it exceptional, but it's a damn solid idler for people who like fish but don't want to worry about them dying. 3/5, good game and exceptionally worth its asking price.

TL;DR: A fun, easy-peasy aquarium game that focuses on collection. There are many varied fish types to collect! It is intuitive and easy. Recommended! 

The Good
- loads of types of fish + upgrades to earn
- lots of variants + pretty fish to look at
- upgrade system seems to be scaled pretty well (it took me about a week using 10-15 minutes daily to earn my first saltwater fish, at 200k)

The Meh
- If you're like me and you want to collect all the rainbow + golden fish, it's ... a slog. I think you could keep the spawn rates of these the same - the annoying part is having to click and add baby fish to my tank just to sell them immediately. If you're going to buying thousands of fish to get all the golds / rainbows, then maybe streamline the process so it involves less clicking. 
- I'm personally not a huge fan of the tank decorations. I wish we could change their overall size.

a feature i thought of while playing that'd be cool to see is the ability to individually scale fish, so we can size our fish realistically in contrast to each other, or just... size them however, like having giant shrimp or something.

If you use an autoclicker, set it to 80ms per (double)-right click.  Around 76 is when the fish don't seem to work properly with the food, so use 80 as a sweet spot.  Plus, if you use it near the side of the tank, they will centre on the food a lot more and you can set another auto clicker for left mouse to dismiss new fish discoveries while auto-feeding.

i love love love this game, it brings me so much joy and peace. the fish are wonderfully designed, the art is lovely. i appreciated the changes in the latest patch a lot! the rebalance was needed, the food xp upgrades are very nice. i do have a couple of suggestions: 

- please allow us to change the light intensity (or color opacity) in each tank! the cool blue lights in particular are really overwhelming and make the tank look super dark. i'd like to be able to tweak the intensity of the colored lights. (this has been changed since my review!! i doubt it was bc of my suggestion, since it happened overnight, but thank you!!)
- it would be really nice to have an option to auto-lock new fish! idk if this makes things too "easy" (for lack of a better term) by taking some of the legwork out of collecting, but i thought it merited suggesting!
- similarly, the option to auto-lock specific fish (maybe through the fish encyclopedia?) would be nice as well, but again, idk if this fits into your vision in terms of work/automation balance.
- these two are ostensibly a lot more work on your end, but still seem possible for future expansion of the game: blurbs in the fish encyclopedia to teach us about the fish (could even just be a little trivia fact for each one), and unique animations for all or rare fish (really i just want the pufferfish to puff tbh). maybe even just unique animations in the encyclopedia vs live in the tank.
- more tank decor options in general, but specifically maybe floating decor at the top of the tank? also idk but i feel the tank decor price curve is a little steep? maybe i'm just playing slowly tho!

overall it's an incredible game and i am super glad i bought it, i would buy it ten more times (i'm gonna buy it for any of my friends who will let me). thank you!!

Chillquarium is a fun, relaxing idle game and I recommend you giving it a try!

Chillquarium is exactly what you'd think. An aquarium idle game with a little bit of RNG thrown into the mix. The game-play is simple. You buy fish, and let them grow. If you want them to grow faster, you can feed them. Eventually they will become adults. You can either sell them, or let them earn passive money for you by simply existing. As you gain more money you can buy bigger/better fish, pebbles, lighting, and decorations. You get "packs" of fish and and sometimes you get rare/epic/legendary fish in those packs.

So what's the appeal then? Well the first fun thing to do is to try and get bigger, better, and rarer fish. (Gotta collect 'em all!) As you get farther in the game it's relaxing to just watch fish swim around. There were days I would just leave this running on one of my monitors and check on it every once in a while.

I could see this game being used as a fun backdrop for a business. Don't want to pay for an aquarium and maintenance? Just leave a computer on running this in the background for people to watch in a waiting room or something.

While the game is good as is, below are some things that would be cool to see in the game:
- More animations for the fish to feel more "alive". For example moving their fins.
- More decorations
- Decorations should move. For example the chest that opens/closes. A diver moving up and down.
- More interaction with the decorations. For example having the fish go behind them, hide in them, etc.
- Able to change the background. The only option right now is a wavy background. It would be nice to have different pictures.
- More "stuff" like maybe adding a filter to make it look more real.
- Maybe fish can have babies?
- More sounds like more bubbles, filter, splashing sounds
- An option to replace the textures with more lifelike ones (Ability to mod the game?)
- Huge tanks/pools to hold huge fish like humpback whales, orcas, dolphins, etc.
- Creatures that crawl on the ground able to move in every direction, rather than just horizontal.

Give it a try and watch some fish!
