Fishing: the original gacha

EDIT: Back to loving again. Yeah, it was a shock after all the anticipation of FINALLY being able to afford something that would make a difference; I mean, I had it timed to the hour, pretty much...I didn't even notice that the icon had moved, and that the price had gone up, for like 10 seconds...I just thought I'd not cleared enough space, duh. 

Anyway, once I was able to start getting the Marine Dwellers, it has started to go at a better pace. I don't think I'll make enough for the Giants for ages now, as the prices have gone up so  substantially. But, it's your game. Do what you will. I don't want this to be a game I associate with anything but positivity; between this an 'A Kinder World' on mobile, I need that bit of chill time to bring me down off the ledge. Neither are super-intensive, and you truly actively play for mere minutes...but I like to just listen to the music in the background, and watch my fish swimming around. :-)

I was initially hesitant about this game as it started off really slowly, even for an idle game. However, after you get into it a little bit and start earning enough income to get more fish at a time, it becomes incredibly fun and rewarding!! I love how fun and flexible it all is! You can play to collect fish, simply to raise fish, to have a themed tank (such as a red tank, a golden tank, etc. as shown in the example video), to have one of each kind of fish, or to have a school made entirely of one kind of fish! There's just no limits here! 

My biggest complaint is the price of saltwater fish. I had to save up enough for the saltwater tank, and then let it sit empty until I could afford my first pack of saltwater fish. This hasn't happened with my other tanks as it's usually pretty balanced.

I also wish that when viewing fish in one tank, it put the locked fish at the top of the list for all fish of that kind. For example, if I have 5 goldfish all the same color/income/everything, sometimes the locked fish will be listed in the middle of those 5 instead of at the top (or bottom). I just want the locked fish to show some sort of priority compared to non-locked fish of the same type. I personally do this because I want to keep one of each kind of fish in the tank to have some diversity, but I need to manually scroll through to make sure I have one of each type locked. Having a setting to keep one of each type locked would be nice as well. It's not a big deal, and sometimes it's actually relaxing to go through each fish manually, but considering that I do this every time I want to buy new fish it can get repetitive if I play a lot in one day.

The recent change to feeding (allowing money to be spent to increase exp from food) is a brilliant change that makes me feel like actively spending time feeding my fish to grow them up is rewarding. On top of that, adult fish no longer eat feed, which means all the exp from food goes to the baby fish that can actually use it.

Great changes! Thank you for listening to your community!

Some additional changes that I suggest:
* Once you have unlocked all the common fish of a particular pack, increase odds to get the painted fish of the same type. Then, once the player has all of the painted fish unlocked, increase odds for golden fish to appear. I guess this is similar to the shiny charm in Pokemon.

* Add mass pack buying option. I'm trying to get all the golden fish for each pack (starting with the first). I'm doing this by emptying out an aquarium then buying 25 packs and opening all of them. If I don't get anything I need, sell all and repeat. The one issue is that I feel I'm getting RSI from clicking 25 times each time. Maybe add an option to specify the number of packs you buy (e.g. 5, 10, 25)

* And finally, and FPS limiter. This game is beautiful, don't get me wrong, but I don't need it running at 144fps on my laptop

Kind Regards,

The game is new but after getting everything, there isn't anything to bring me back. After unlocking everything, there isn't anything to bring me back. Buying giant packs are slow and you can only buy one at a time which makes trying to unlock golden or rainbow fish not fun at all.

First things first. This is an IDLE game. Honestly there isn't much to do other than buy fish and let them grow in real time. The food you feed them to make them grow faster doesn't scale with the more expensive fish which can be really annoying when the second pack common fish take like, 2 days to mature (don't even get me started on some of the others). HOWEVER, that's kind of the point. I actually really like that this game forces you to have slow progression. It means that you can't get everything within a day and never open the game again. Just a fair warning the price gouging for the fish feels really unfair but again, I like this aspect. It forces you to buy fish of one tier a lot and see more and more of those fish before just moving on to the next one and overwhelming you trying to get all the different versions. Every big purchase of this game feels more earned since you literally had to wait for it (and for your fish to make money for you). If you're a perfectionist with games like this you might hate the RNG for the Goldens but hey, that's why they're rare. I love the art of this game but I do wish the background had a little more going on (or at least let me buy stuff for the background it's pretty boring). Overall this is one of the better Idle games I've played as it's actually an Idle game that still lets you control everything without overwhelming you or taking up too much time when checking up on it.

(Also bonus perk the in-game money accumulates for up to a week!)

However, no cloud-saves just cost me about a month worth of progress and with how slow the start of the game is I doubt I'm going to try and get that progress back.

So, one of the negative review talks about how this is just a game where you get on, sell grown fish, buy new fish and then nothing except wait to login again.

And that's basically true, but I think rating it down for that is unfair - that's what the game says it is, it's what it says on the tin.  That's like rating down a shooter for being violent.  This is a chill, idle aquarium-based creature collector.  If that's what you like, then this is a nice game for you.  If not, then don't get it.

If I have any caveats, they're mostly things other folks mentioned: the increment scaling is off - it takes 3 real weeks to get enough fish to make the cash to get a second fish tank and start the second batch of fish.
It would be nice if there were more tank animations - bubbles occasionally, or pond/seaweed that waves back and forth, that sort of thing.  And there should be advanced fish packs for more money that have increased chances of painted/golden fish.

But for the cheap, sub $5 price, this is a nice, laid-back, relaxing RNG creature collector.

The only reason I am giving this game negative review is because their save system needs reworking. After playing for 70+ hrs, I had almost met the goal of getting Giants and due to my system crash, save data got corrupted and everything reset. This should not happen. Game should not go back to 0 after a computer crash. I have no inclination of starting from scratch again.

Overall, Chillquarium lives up to its name. Its a chill game about a fish aquarium. It is a really nice game to have on your second monitor as youre watching a show or playing another game that may take more of your attention. I also love the fact that the game has a fish collection page that shows you what fish you have (including painted and golden). There are also rainbow fish which are extremely rare and I have yet to come across. Another thing I love is the fact that you dont even have to have the game open for your fish to grow and earn more money. This is a great game that I will continue to play and expect more great things from in the future!

Review as of 29/09/2023:

I bought this after seeing the 1.0 release on my front page. The game itself is *incredibly* bare bones - I understand that it is going for the cute, cosy, 'just vibes' type of game; but there really isn't much game at all even for that. Fish growth times are initially long and only grow longer (the middle tier of the penultimate fish type taking close to a week to mature). There is no way to upgrade how much the food pellets take off of each fish's timer, and their AI often causes lag if you have the full tank swimming around your held-down mouse (on a 4070Ti).

The different colour-rarities of fish is a unique mechanic that I like. However, the percentage chance to get them is far too low, especially since collecting all of them for each tier is tied to all of the games achievements. I'm certain that they've been unlocked using SAM, as I do not believe the percentage of people having sat there holding an auto-clicker buying, opening, and mass selling fish for what I would estimate to be days at a time for *each* tier, let alone the time it would take to accrue the money required to do it for the higher tier fish.

Overall, this is either an alpha build of a very good idle game, or its a screensaver that you need to have open and actively click on occasionally to get the cool effects on. Good potential, but not worth it unless you have money burning a hole in your pocket.

This game is really nothing more than a simple idle fish tank simulator game, as you can see I've been running it pretty steadily for a couple weeks now.
I really do enjoy it, the fish are cute.
It is however, extremely slow paced. It takes a very long time for most of the fish to mature, and accumulating money to upgrade and move on to new fish types is a very long process. I've put in daily dedication to this game and JUST started being able to afford saltwater fish.
I'm perfectly fine with that level of progression, I also really like that every fish has a painted and a golden variation, it tickles my collector brain.
One thing that I do find VASTLY lacking however is the sad few options for tank decor. With just over half a dozen sculptures. I would love to see an update in the future with an addition of plants, seashells, and other fun varieties of tank decor. It's very boring having all my hard earned tanks looking identical!
All in all, it is a cute desktop buddy idle fish tank game. Not particularly engaging but still enjoyable, worth the price.

I like the fact when you buy fish you get at least a x2 or greater return upon sale, and not only that, the fish also give you passive income if you don't sell right away, meaning the cash you got can only go up, the only "Soft Lock" I can even remotely think of is if you spent all your fish then bought like a tank upgrade or deco for instance bringing your cash lower than the lowest pack, if that was to be the case then yeah that could literally get any player in trouble at any level actually lols. Other than that you buy fish you feed fish you sell fish, you do get offline rewards up to a week I heard, and it seems true I logged off many times today for different amounts of time and I get my dollars and cents I so deserve. It's definitely worth the Steam Cost! Just always at all times keep at least x2 Fish in the tank, and click the "Lock" on the ones you want to always stay in btw cuz those won't sell in case you slip up and sell all by mistake otherwise I could see another potential "Soft Lock" opportunity actually.

As an aquarium nerd, I was elated to stumble upon Chillquarium on its release day.  The concept may seem overly simple, and even my kids made me feel silly for purchasing this...but then they discovered the addicting loop of opening fish packs, selling commons, and buying more fish.  We're all hooked!  The fact that this game is around 5 bucks and has no in-game transactions is impressive as well.  It's 100% worth it for the hours of fun you'll have...and don't worry about overfeeding your fishy friends, as there's no nitrogen cycle in Chillquarium. :) 

Although I adore the game, there are a few requests I'd make for future updates.  An option to tick the music on a continuous loop instead of random bursts of relaxing tunes would be appreciated.  I'd also love a cloud save feature so I didn't have to have two separate Chillquarium games for my two PCs.  Finally, a few more options within settings (such as FPS and graphics) would be nice.

If you like idle and collection games, then I highly recommend Chillquarium!  View my full review video on YouTube: https://youtu.be/12JGN_-8Wcc?si=CwXRKNoPDEfp5Kl8.

I tend to get burned out on idle-ish games like this because they start to feel tedious and like they are wasting my time. This game is well-designed and hits just the right balance between giving me enough to do and not being too overwhelming.

You buy fish in randomized packs that cost some amount of in-game currency. The fish start out as baby fish and after some amount of time based on their rarity they become adult fish that earn a certain amount of in-game currency per day. You can always sell adult fish for more more than the original cost of the pack, so you never really have any risk of losing money. Feeding the fish by right-clicking makes them grow faster. If you close the game, the fish continue to earn money until the next time you open the game. Over time you earn more money per day and sell enough fish to reach the cost of the next level of pack, which then gives a big spike in potential money. You can also spend money on cosmetic upgrades and additional tanks that hold more fish.

The gameplay is very simple and that's a good thing, you can leave it running all the time and only actually interact with it a few times a day. Beyond that, the visuals of the game acts like an animated desktop background and help actually feel like a benefit of collecting fish and making upgrades. The fish designs are cute and it's easy to pick favorites and name them. It does not feel at all like a mobile game with a brutal or confusing in-game economy, you can rush to grow and sell fish as quickly as possible or take your time and have a more relaxed pace. There's enough to do in the game that you can play it for weeks and still have new things to collect or unlock.

If you have some spare time and money I'd try it out.

I don't have time to play games much anymore, nor do many hold my attention, and I have already explored about as much of Cookie Clicker as I think is humanly possible. So I went looking to see if there were any interesting idle games. This was the second result in the Idlers tag. I already like aquariums and fish so I downloaded the demo and played for about 10 mins before purchasing the full game. It is a very good use of $6.

I like that this game forces you to be patient. One of the biggest annoyances for me these days is the obsession with "min maxing" and "racing" to complete everything in a game first. This game has no micro transactions or anything like that. If you get a rare fish you are waiting the 3 days for it to grow up. The upgrades appear at first to have ridiculous pricing, but you will notice the more rare fish you get, the more income they draw in cumulatively over time. So there is the satisfaction of checking the game before and after work, before and after you go to bed/ wake up, to see what has changed/ that number slowly beginning to tick up faster. 

It is the perfect game for someone who wants to "play a game" but doesn't have 300 hours to set aside. Seriously, I purchased BG3 and recently re downloaded Destiny 2 and this game has held my attention more than either of those, and I've probably only spent an hour total actually looking at it. 

It has lovely artwork, with many different kinds of fish in it (And I havent even scratched the surface yet, I've still only seen the freshwater stuff). It has small but satisfying little sound effects. I'm very impressed and pleased by the artwork and sounds, and I think the person that made this should be very proud of what they've made.
It is a fun mix of gacha and idle.

In its current state, I think a few features kinda sour it. That won't be the case for everyone, but it is for me. As other reviews mention, it's a chill fish game. If that's all it tried to be, I wouldn't complain. I picked this up while I was sick and it was a nice low effort game to pass the week, I feel bad complaining but it's where I'm at. None of this is personal against the dev; keep up the good work and good luck in school.

The game has several variants of each fish, each rarer than the last. Painted and Golden variants both give achievements for collecting all of them from a set. Even if you have this game in the background for months on end, I think you'll eventually decide to try and grind out the achievements with your infinite amounts of money. 

I've spent somewhere between 2 and 4 hours JUST opening packs from the first set for goldens, and I'm still missing one golden legendary, and there's still 4 other sets of packs after that. I earn enough money to buy thousands of these packs per second, but can only buy 25 at a time before I have to clear them out of my tank. The game needs at minimum a UI upgrade for churning through packs like this, but preferably a system to increase the odds so you don't need to buy and sell so many fish to find rare variants. It can cost unreasonable amounts of money, it just needs to save time. The current methods of grinding don't fit well with the otherwise low effort gameplay; it's very not chill.

If that grind gets fixed, I think it'll be back to a chill little fish game.

this is THE aquarium game . if you are looking though reviews and see people complaining about progression and the cost of fish, then you are reading the reviews of people who did not read the description of the game, most negative reviews just don't get the point, its not supposed to be fast its not supposed to constantly give you progression dopamine, its just a cute chill indie game about growing fish selling fish and SLOWLY creating the tank you want, its simple concise and to the point. 
on another point some fish literally take days to grow, some take hours, and some take minutes. if you are expecting a high octain fish hatchery than you are at the wrong location only chill no stress game play. and not one moment are you pressured to progress or do anything, you could just sit with the base tank of 60 fish and just watch them swim. the getting new fish and growing your tank feels kinda secondary like just a thing for you to do like a never ending side quest that only really ends when you want it too or i guess till you fill out the fish dex its one of those games where you can either experience the whole game in 1 hour or a few hundred (probably thousands if i'm being real) its your own little fishy journey and the fish will always be there in the chillquarium, chilling.

PS (if you really just want to grow your fish fastly you can just use auto clicker, but your fish don't make and aren't worth a more than if you grew them naturally)

It's great if you want an idler that you can check on a couple minutes a day, but it's also great if you want the dopamine rush of opening a pack of trading cards without having to spend any real life money (beyond what you would pay for the game, anyway). When I have free time I tear through packs of hundreds of fish hunting for golds and rainbows like shiny Pokemon (to my fellow shiny hunters out there - hi!)

highly priced for what it is

Nothing like I expected, 

I purchased this game for $5 on sale and I feel like I stole it, the amount of passion that must have gone into the creation of this game is outstanding. I've almost completed Rivers and Ponds, but I can already tell that the attention to detail for each fish will continue to impress me. I adore the painted versions as they bring a great amount of variety to the fish. Golden versions are also super fun to collect, and the other secret rarity that I've just discovered. 

My biggest surprise was finding out there are no micro transactions, and to that I give a very large applause, it would be so easy to just stick in "extra tank, $15usd" but not doing so shows a great amount of integrity, and as a player I feel good just playing the game. many pay-to-win style games make free-to-play players subconsciously feel not as invested. 

My only suggestions would be that I feel the current selection of fish (while amazing and already vast) could definitely be expanded upon to include other types of aquatic life! The addition of aquatic plants would be fantastic as a secondary way to decorate or even gain more passive income. 

Again, I have only seen about 35% of the fish in the game so I may update my review later on talking about potential new fish, but currently I am more than satisfied with my purchase of this game and I hope that it gets even more support so that updates, DLC, and even potential merch could be available in the future.

also, shoutout to TheSatinUnicorn on twitch! They are currently streaming the game all the time so please go check them out!

As the name suggests, Chillquarium is a very chill game. Having played the demo, I love the addition of the fish packs. It triggers the same sort of dopamine rush of opening packs in other games. Instead of being disappointed with cosmetics you will never use, like in other games, you are rewarded with all sorts of cute fishes that will make you money. Having different variants of fishes is also a fun addition to spice up opening packs. I know the developer is very passionate about the game, so I have no doubts there will be plenty of new content to come. Although the pacing may be slow for some, I happen to think the pacing of getting new fish and cosmetics is very well thought out. I am very excited to see what else will be added the game!

Even for an idle game it feels way too slow and the balancing feels off (the epic fish that matured in 2 days makes less than the epic fish that matured in 1 day). Fish only make money once a day, reducing your main income to selling your fish. There's no meaningful interaction other than holding right click to feed and even that is really only good for growing the fish that take minutes to mature. Trying to feed to boost the hours or days fish feels awful. No upgrades other than more tank space and more tanks. It's something you check on every few hours while you do something else. Which is fine if that's the kind of game you want, I just like a little faster pace and interaction in my idlers.

So as of this review, the game is still in 1.0, so it's pretty barebones. There's not much to do because this game is still what I would consider in its infancy. There is a cheese strat where you can auto-feed your fish, so that helps progress a ton currently. Hopefully future updates bring an auto-feed system or something similar. So far progress seems reasonable, and the game seems like it has a lot of potential with a lot of future possibility. There is no microtransaction system, which is great, and hopefully it stays like that. It even goes as far as feeding a "gacha itch" with in-game currency, since obtaining fish is based on a gacha system that gives you a chance at rarer fish that bring more income to buy more packs and pull for more fish. $6 might be a bit steep, but the developer was generous enough to have the game on sale for release week. In the future, there will hopefully be enough content added to fill the $6 worth of this game. Based on seeing the interaction of the developer with this game also, you can tell they love the game and love to create for it. They seem to do a lot of brainstorming and listen to player feedback, which is pretty rare for a lot of game developers these days. All in all, I look forward to what this game may bring in the future. I would love to see more systems like auto-feeding, maybe feed upgrades, more tiers of different fish to fill the gaps of how far between the current price of fish are, etc. But I mean, for the $5 this game currently is? It's definitely worth giving a shot if you haven't yet. If anything, it's relaxing and cute and a nice background on a 2nd monitor.

Edit: This game does become somewhat active when you begin filling your fish pokedex. Getting the golden set for the first pack of fish alone took me 6 hours of nonstop play. While it's not much for active play, it's definitely a grind and a half. I was stuck on 23/25 fish for 5 out of 6 of those hours until I figured out growing up the gold babies I already have increases my chances of getting new goldens. As soon as I grew the babies, I got the Koi instantly which was one of the 2 I was missing. The Discus came about 45 mins later to finish the set.

This is unfortunately a pretty uninspired idle game. It has potential, but lacks the constant dopamine hit of unlocks and evolution. The gap between unlocks is really significant and you need to hold down the right mouse button for hundreds of hours just to get to the next tier. Considering that's about all you can do in the game, and there's no challenge or strategy to it, this could've just been called "right click simulator" and it would've been pretty accurate.

I saw someone refer to this as a glorified screensaver and honestly, that's exactly what it feels like. There's potential, but not enough in it to justify the price. Were it a free title, I would certainly recommend picking it up, but not as a paid product.

I respect that the dev says that there's more coming, but really, this shouldn't have shipped in its current form. It's a long way from finished.

Edit: A great update came out today, the dev seems dedicated to ensuring the game improves.

I really like it but there are definitley some improvements that need to be made regarding the UI. It also really needs an autoclick for feeding with the mouse so you don't have to sit there holding the button. 

Let me explain what exactly this game is.. It's an idler. There's no real goal. You buy fish, they grow, you get better fish. There's no alien attacks or anything like that. This is not Insaniquarium or Feeding Frenzy. The progression is very slow. The slowest I've ever seen in any game. The game progresses when it is closed thankfully, so you don't need to have it opened 24/7. 

There are 5 tiers of fish. Those for $5, $1000, $200,000, $40,000,000, and $8,000,000,000. Each one of these tiers contain A LOT of different fish. There's a bunch of different ones to look at. You can name your fish and customize your tank as well!

You earn money very slowly at the start. I got the game yesterday and right now I have just $500. I've been very good at keeping up with it as well,  

Ultimately, if you get bored very easily then this is not for you. This game is a chore, and that's why it's fine. It's not for everyone. If you liked Neopets type games as a kid then you will absolutely love this.

Chillquarium has lived up to it's name! It's a very laid back, AFK or second screen game. The progression early on is fairly slow, however the fantastic art, extremely lightweight performance, and ambience of the many colourful fish make this an instant win.

Another HUGE plus is the complete and utter lack of microtransactions that could have riddled this game like so many others.

I'm glad the developer is actively reading feedback and planning to add more to this game, but currently there isn't much to do at all in the game other than hold right click and watch all the fish move towards the food pellets like a giant hive mind (there's no hunger system or anything to make the fish behave uniquely), then you close the game after a couple minutes and wait until tomorrow when all your fish have grown and you have money so you can click on a few cosmetic upgrades (nothing makes the food better, encourages active gameplay, etc. like you'd expect from idle games), then you buy new fish and close the game until tomorrow. The premise is fine and the graphics are okay (I wish the tank background was not static) but there isn't anything to do even from the first minutes of gameplay, and no way to scale up anything in a meaningful way since the money just goes right back into getting more fish exclusively to get money again. 

There seems to be a lack of imagination for how to make the progression interesting or the fish simulation realistic. How about a way to make the food stronger, make the tank encourage a faster rate of fish growth per decoration item, a way to increase/decrease salinity, turbidity, acidity, temperature, etc. to accommodate fish types, have multiple tanks displayed on a wall of fish tanks you can move around to see your full collection at once, a breeding system to automate fish production so you can micromanage male/female fish of each type and their habitats to increase breeding rate, idk just something to make it more of a game. Right now it is just "you can feed them and they grow once" and that's as far as they thought it through I guess. The UI has nice polish aside from some QoL issues like no "sell all duplicates" or something.

Dive into Chillquarium: The Ultimate Aquarium Management Experience!

Hey there, fellow gamers and aquatic enthusiasts! Allow me to share my exhilarating experience with an exceptional game that has managed to capture my heart and imagination: the one-of-a-kind "Chillquarium" – the ultimate aquarium management game!

As a professional gamer, I'm always on the lookout for immersive, relaxing experiences that help me unwind after those intense gaming sessions. And as a professional fish breeder, I have a deep appreciation for aquatic life. "Chillquarium" brings these two worlds together in a way that's simply astounding.

After a long day of competitive gaming or tending to my real-life fish, "Chillquarium" serves as a perfect escape into a soothing world. The calming soundtrack, the gentle ripple of water, and the serene ambiance create an atmosphere of pure tranquility. It's the ideal game to unwind and find your inner peace.

In conclusion, "Chillquarium" is not just a game; it's an immersive, educational, and utterly captivating journey into the world of aquarium management. As both a professional gamer and a professional fish breeder, I can't recommend this game highly enough. It offers a unique blend of relaxation, and creativity that will keep you hooked for hours on end. So, dive in, create your underwater masterpiece, and let "Chillquarium" whisk you away into a world of aquatic serenity. Happy gaming, fellow aquarists! 🐠🌊

Let’s call it what it is: [b]Chillquarium is essentially a screensaver[/b].

In my country this game is almost $10 after tax at full price; almost [b]double[/b] the cost compared to games like Cookie Clicker & Melvor Idle. I understand this game is made by one person but, in my opinion, Chillquarium is being priced at an unreasonable level for what the game offers. 

The gameplay loop is very simple and extremely linear (which I like but some might not): Buy packs of baby fish, put them in the tank, wait for them to mature, sell them to buy BETTER packs of BETTER baby fish.

Very simple premise, the graphics are surprisingly interesting to look at for pixel art, and it looks great as a screensaver on my 2nd monitor. Unfortunately, [b]as I’ve hopefully made clear[/b], the price point is pretty high for what Chillquarium offers in terms of gameplay. If you’re looking for an interactive fish-themed wallpaper, just use wallpaper engine [i](which is ironically cheaper than this game)[/i]. 

[b]My honest recommendation[/b], for now, is to play the DEMO. If it’s a [i]low-interactive aquarium screensaver[/i] you’re looking for, the demo offers it for FREE and does not expire (just blocks off some of the types of fish you can buy). Therefore, I am refunding the product at the price point it's currently at. I will 100% be wishlisting this item; [b]but it’s an unjustifiable cost-to-value ratio for an idle game of this caliber[/b]. 

I have thousands of hours in idle games and have fully 100% completed many on steam (screenshot of a couple: https://gyazo.com/139c908a00c0bc60985b2ba0c4150d33). This means I've [b]paid[/b] for many idle games, as well as tried free ones. If I was to price this game off my experience [i]considering it’s an indie studio, content level, progression, etc[/i]… my fair market value estimate would be around $2 USD. If there’s a sale that drops it around that price, I will happily pick it up again.

As a former freshwater aquarium hobbyist, I love Chillquarium!

Would love to see an update for general fish behaviours, eg. bottom feeders keeping to the bottom of the tank rather than swimming all around, but it is otherwise super chill. Slightly quicker progression would be nice because I want to build my dream fishy community but need to discover them all. 

The chill mode addition is great :) Thanks for making an awesome lil game.

This is the idle game i always wanted, already ticks most of the boxes of a great idle but i'm curious what will be added next.

While the idea of opening fish packs is appealing, there's a major issue with their scarcity and pricing. The first packs cost $5, but then the price skyrockets to $1,000 for the next one. Considering that many of the fish are sold for a mere $2-$4, this turns the game into a idle grind. I managed to unlock all the fish in the $5 packs before I even had half the money I needed for the next pack. It would have been far better to have more fish packs with different rarity percentages, to create a sense of progression.

There are other items available for purchase, such as pebbles, lights, and decorations. Unfortunately, these items serve no purpose in the game except to drain your finances, and they don't contribute anything visually engaging.

The only interaction available in the game is right-clicking to feed the fish, which provides them with a measly +5 experience points. Given that many fish require well over 100,000 points to grow, this +5 boost is inconsequential. One would expect that purchasing accessories might increase this bonus, for people that want a bit more active play, but sadly, that's not the case.

Regarding the idea of having the game run in the background for relaxation, it falls short on this front as well. The music is ok but the effects are grating with no real control over this, and the graphics appear distorted with the fish just bouncing back and forth and does not feel natural nor do they school. There is also no attention to scaling. Oscar, neon tetra, goldfish—they all look essentially the same size.

While you can lock fish you don't want to sell, that's about the extent of it. There is no control if you want to collect golden  or rainbow versions of every fish. Overall, this game lacks substance and, considering its shortcomings, it's simply not worth the money.

This is an absolutely fantastic little game. It's already got me hooked! I love the style. Just hop in for a bit here and there and play for a while, then hop out while your fishies grow. There isn't a huge amount to do at any one time, but the excitement of checking in and seeing what has grown and how much money I've gotten is addictive. 

There is a lot of love poured into this game. You can tell with the sprites, the research done into real, actual fish species that show up, and how the game is priced fairly with no microtransactions to be found. Seriously, thank you devs!

It's very important to emphasis before anything else that this is an idle game. You don't interact with it much, you just let it be and occasionally buy and sell your fish. The game keeps track of everything and will give you money even when it's not running (you get a cash boost when you boot it up again). If you want an interactive kind of game, this [i]really[/i] is not it.

That said! I like it. It's nice and chill and watching the fish swim around is kind of peaceful. You can leave it running while you do something else, or just open it up once a day and adjust your fish and then shut it down until you next want to check on it.

There isn't much to it right now, in that there isn't any reason for decorations aside from to decorate, and there isn't any feeding automation (though you don't have to feed you fish if you don't want to). The fish don't have any kind of animation aside from swimming back and forth.

But personally I'm not bothered by that all that much. I enjoy just watching the fish, it helps the brain chill out and it's fun seeing new fish unlock even if it can be slow. Enjoyable if you don't mind that it's designed to be progressed through slowly.

This game is an Interactive Screensaver.
	I know that the title is a little bit rude, after all this game is “supposed” to be a screensaver, right? Chillquarium communicates a vibe of relaxation and idle sensation in its art style and gentle guitar ambiance. However, at the heart of this game is a grossly malicious time waster of half implemented mechanics and what to me reads as developmental neglect or incomplete design. From the music cutting in and out (going silent often for minutes at a time), to the absurd wait times for basic progress in the game’s myriad meters and features, Chillquarium makes me feel anything but chill. Annoyance and frustration at something which feels like it could have respected my extremely limited time on this planet is going to come up a lot during this review. For the price, this is an overly expensive and fiddly screensaver that fails to appreciate your 5 or 6 dollars US. I see potential in this game, but I am driving myself mad with “coulds and shoulds” and it honestly feels like highway banditry at the end of the day. If this game is found to have a Crypto Miner or something attached to it, I wouldn’t be shocked, and yes I am going to level that possibility squarely because I cannot explain its lackadaisical pace of progression and reward without factoring in some kind of rude profit margin.
	Let’s begin at the basics of this game, then once I lay out the systems I will then explain why even cheating at the game with an Autoclicker is a waste of time, and there are far better games that have more interesting in them to explore, even involving fish!

Mechanics Overview:
	In Chillquarium, the objective of the game is to fill your premium, $6 US screensaver environment with fish, and you get a head start on this with a slap on the ass of $20 and a very mobile-style tutorial which tells you to open the shop, purchase 4 packs of fish, and then unbox them into the aquarium. The packs themselves open with some fanfare, showing off different ‘rarities’ of fish and silhouetting unknown fish, naming them as “???” so as to pique your curiosity as to what fish it could be. The fish spawn in as little babies, and swim around randomly using the finest of Motion Tween + Stretch, Skew, and Squish this side of Adobe Flash 2.0. By right-clicking, you can feed your fish using a pellet of fish food that explodes into XP in a radius that’s maybe 150 pixels wide. The radius means you can hit multiple fish at a time and if you hold right-click it will spawn about 10 pellets per second. For your first few fish, you might get lucky and get a few Goldfish which rapidly grow up into adults with food. The fish swim around somewhat haphazardly when you are feeding, attracted like asteroids to the gravity well but often times circling eventually in an asymptotic manner, so feeding your fish to raise their XP and get them to grow into adults is a bit frustrating.
	Like real fish, your digital fish sprites are hard to hit dead-on, and are slippery enough that it takes a pretty active amount of mouse movement to school them together into a ball, so as to raise as many at once with your force-feeding technique. The fish don’t experience hunger or satiation, so you can feed them indefinitely for hours and hours and they will eventually mature into an Adult Fish. An Adult fish once discovered shows off a one-time pop up indicating its name, and every time the box is dismissed by clicking “Awesome”. You can’t really skip this box and it doesn’t pause the game, it instead releases your mouse input, and your ball of fish that you were feeding will typically scatter right after. When fish mature there’s a cute “pop” noise, but this quickly becomes grating due to how many fish you will need to raise so-as to afford new things. Much like a real life aquarium, there is no escape from the demands of capitalism and once turned into adults, your fish will generate an income value per day (at first, less than a dollar of in-game currency per day), and be listed with a sale value that is usually underwhelming. There are 5 tiers of fish and the march from Tier 1 to Tier 3 was very much a waste of my time, so I probably won’t continue towards Tier 5 unless this game gets major updates and revisions.
	Cash-wise, you have the kind of progression of value that resembles many clicker and idler style games. Your first tier of Fish costs $5 per 4x fish, and the immediate second tier of Fish costs $1000! The first fish in the game cap out at sale prices of around $50, so that means raising a lot of fish so you can get your first Tier 2 pack, which again is 4x fish, and again their sale value is a bit shoddy because Tier 3 Fish cost $200,000 per pack of four. Also Tier 3 and up fish are Saltwater Fish, so you also have to purchase a $300,000 Saltwater Fish Tank. Not only are the values absurdly inflated, but the math starts getting kind of hard to even fathom because your progression is in such huge chunks. In Cookie Clicker, for example, your first upgrades are 5 or 10 cookies, and you gradually build up to several thousand and then a million cookie upgrades. The scale of numbers exists, but this game doesn’t make use of it nor does it seem to care about the obvious grind and gulf between your time expenditure and the money you make per fish. You see, I skipped the part where Fish grow naturally, and when you unbox them each Fish has a time listed that they take to grow naturally. The accrual rate of growth is based upon 1 XP per second, and particularly for fish that take days to grow… it tends not to be precise.
	In 1 hour, a fish grows 3600 XP. The most valuable fish in your current Tier will be north of 100k XP each, for example the highest Tier 2 fish is 504,000 XP, which translates to 140 Hours (5.84 days) of natural growth time. You obviously want to shave as much time as possible off of these waits by feeding your fish, and doing so will help as a single hit of fish food will grant 5 XP to all fish in the radius of the explosion. But, here’s the issue: We’re looking at 100,800 hits for that one fish. The quickest to age fish has 900 XP, so it takes 15 minutes (180 hits of food, if you will) to hit Adulthood. By default you can hold right click to spam roughly 10 hits of food per second, which means that a single Goldfish requires about 18 seconds of continuous hitting to mature. This seems fine by itself, but the problem scales rapidly into that 504,000 XP / 100,800 hit fish, and at 10 hits per second, that means the fish takes 168 minutes of continuous right-click and on-target hitting. I’ve fought MMO Raid Bosses solo that take less time to whittle down, you can grind out like 80 levels in World of Warcraft in that time these days. This is a humiliatingly long grind to unlock a single fish, so it is telling that one of the first documented community guides to this game is about strategies to use an Auto-clicker.

How cheating exposes problem:
	For a game to be chill, I don’t want it to feel like it is begging me to give it attention every day, I don’t want all of these literal fish-hook mechanics to be dangled infront of my face. With lots of unlockable fish, random chance lootpacks giving you ‘rare’ fish, and a cost model that means hours and hours and hours of uncomfortable grinding and right-mouse holding, it becomes a question of WHY. Why is this game so eager to make you hurry up and wait, to burn literally over 2 hours of continuous fish feeding action on a single rare fish, when it will simply be sold for less than the immediate next tier’s weak lame common fish!? Why does it cost 1 TRILLION DOLLARS for rainbow tank lights!? That might as well be a joke unlock for finding Fish Hitler in one of your random packs. This is a game that is begging for Gems and other Mobile Garbage to be added to it, with the timers and the futile nature of feeding fish. 

I bet it's harvesting GPU Cycles for Crypto Mining.

For an idle game it lives up to it's name as there's nothing to do but close it down. The feeding system is painfully slow and forces an auto clicker progression. If you go down the auto clicker route and decide to upgrade your tank feeding multiple fish will drop the game to 5-7fps slowing progression even further. There's no background currency generation when the game is open so leaving it on another screen and tending to your fish periodically is futile.

If you want a game where you can look at the fish and don't care about progression or you want to open the game for one minute every day to collect your earnings this is the idle game for you. If you're looking for tank upgrades, buffs, selling strategies, progressive earnings, auto feeding an actual balanced click and idle experience, look elsewhere.

My play time as of writing this review is quite low because I check my fish once per day and then close the game. The great thing about this idle gacha aquarium game is that your fish and income grow even if the game is closed. 

Before buying the base game, I had played the demo for about two months and really enjoyed my time with it! I like the gacha aspect of the game without it requiring me to drain my irl bank account, and I still get excited when I pull a rare variant of a fish for the first time. It's also satisfying for me to see my fish collection grow. I like seeing money number and fish number go up. 

I'm hoping that there will be more buyable active upgrades to help speed up fish growth such as increasing how much xp fish get per pellet of food, because as of now, actively feeding your fish is not that helpful when some fish can take days to grow. Also, it would be nice to be able to (slightly) increase your chance of getting x type of fish (e.g. rare, painted, golden) through a buyable upgrade or accomplishing certain tasks.

I think this game has a lot of potential, and I'm excited to see what's next!

This reminds me of the fish screensavers of long ago so I like having it open on my second monitor. As far as I can tell, though, "screensaver" is pretty much all this game is. 

The basic loop is: Buy fish. Wait for fish to grow up. Sell fish you don't want to keep. Repeat.

There's nothing to do while you wait and some of the fish take a very long time to grow up (6 real life days is the longest I've seen so far) and there isn't anything you can meaningfully do to speed that up. You can feed them but this requires holding down the right mouse button so that's not really viable unless you want to set up an auto-clicker and not use your computer for anything else. As far as I can tell there are no incremental mechanics or upgrades (other than allowing more fish on the screen).

The pixel art of the fish is very good.

Semi-early in the game there's a fish with a higher hourly rate than me. 

10/10 would derive profit from these fishes' labour again.

Basically, you have an aquarium with fish that give you passive income.
You sell fish once they've grown, or you keep them if their income is good.
With the money you get, you buy new fish via a gacha system.

The fish grow in real time, but you are able to speed up their growth by right-clicking to feed them.
Every fish has two rare color variants, with increased value and income.
Every fish and their rare variants are recorded in your Collection. (Your Pokédex)
You can upgrade your fish tank to hold more fish, you can get multiple fish tanks, and you can buy different lights, decorations, and pebbles (the floor) for your fish tank.

The game has a very non-intrusive atmosphere. The ambiance is nice, and the music is very relaxing. It plays every now and then for a short while, and in my five hours of running the game, I have not once been bothered by it.
I'd even be willing to say this is the most relaxing game I've ever played. There is no stress, no fear of missing out, no annoyances, and there is even a "night" mode that turns the light and its ambiance off, if you so wish.
There is also a "Chill Mode", which disables the game's UI. Put the game up on a big screen in your room somewhere with this if you want some nice ambiance. :)

If you are going to buy this, just know that it is VERY idle. Since your fish grow in real-time (for the most part), you'll mostly just be having the game open by the side. This is a good thing in my opinion, as I don't think this game is supposed to be "played". It just sits there, bringing some nice ambiance, but also being very satisfying when you do occasionally tab into it.

Overall, I'm very happy I decided to buy this.
Give it a shot - it's on sale. :)

And for the dev: My one suggestion would be to add a way to cap the game to 60 FPS, or maybe lower, if someone wants that. It's running in the background 95% of the time, so I don't think it needs to be at 160 FPS all the time!

Thank you for reading!

I've just started up, but if you like accumulation and idle games, you'd probably like this. The one feature that I really like is the buying of "fish packs" that give you a variety of random fish with different values. There's not a ton of action in the game, though you can feed the fish to boost their progress, but it's a great game to look in on from time to time. For the price, you'll get a lot of value and a chill experience that can run on a second monitor or just be a game that you manage every few hours or a couple times a day.

Chillquarium is a very hands off idle fish collecting game with gacha mechanics. It's very cute and I really like how vibrant the colors are. There's a little pop sound when your fish become adults, which is a nice touch. Feeding the fish is fun too. (You can hold down the right click on the mouse to keep manually feeding.) I like watching the fish swarm around the food.

I agree with the negative reviews in that the game might be a little too hands off, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, but it's not for everyone. I also wish there were more decorations and an ability to upgrade your food. Overall, it's a fun game and I hope to see it get more updates in the future!

I have to agree with the negative reviews that this game is SO IDLE that unless you just love watching those cute fishes you will quickly start asking yourself what is the point of running this "game".

However, it has a great potential. I posted some suggestions on discord and it seems like the developer is thinking similarly and is not only going to tune the game loop based on the feedback, but also add some QoL and make the collectibles in game more attractive so it's not just visual but has actual impact on the game progress.

Right now, there is a huge gap between active and passive play, something like 4000% difference. It would be great if some mechanic was introduced that would allow automatic feeding with roughly 50% efficiency compared to doing it manually (so active play is still better rewarded). There is even simpler solution - holding right button drops food at 100% rate, while right-clicking once just sets/cancels automatic feeding at clicked location at 50% rate, letting us feed the fish passively and using the mouse somewhere else (making this finally regular idle game).

I have been fishkeeping for several years now, and I initially saw a teaser for this game on the aquariums subreddit. I absolutely love the aesthetic and variety of fish. I'm not too far into the game so I've only experienced the freshwater fish but I am excited to see all the different fish species and rare varieties to unlock.

I would love to see more realistic behaviours added to this game in the future. I noticed that schooling/shoaling fish tend to keep to their own groups and I thought that was a very cool touch. A few examples:
[*]Bottom dwelling species like Corydoras and Shrimp keeping to the bottom 1/3 of the screen.
[*]More realistic scaling between species, in real life Bala Sharks get up to 12inches long and Bettas around 3-4inches, but in the game adult Bettas seem to be significantly bigger.
[*]More realistic interactions between fish, something like more aggressive species hoarding the food pellets from smaller species.
[*]Speed of different fish, Neon Tetras can swim a lot quicker than Guppies or Goldfish.
[*]An option to disable the +xp text that appears whenever fish eat a pellet.

Not all realism aspects would be feasible to implement, but I am definitely looking forward to continuing the game and any new content that might be added later.

I played about 30 hours of the demo version. Its a great idle game for those that don't want to be stuck to the screen actively playing an idle game. Very simple game loop: you buy fish and watch them grow. Once they grow they passively earn you money you use to buy more fish. You can speed up the growing process by feeding them. That is it. 

This is a lot slower of a progression than nearly every other idle I've played so be okay with just logging off the game for the day and pick it back up later when you have more to do. Only thing I wish was different about the game was having more than 24 hours of offline progress tracked. Even just 48 hours would be better.

I recommend this game to those that like idle games buy don't have the time to get invested in tons of mechanics, talent trees, or prestige mechanics. Its just a simple "money goes up slowly" type of game.

I love a good idle sim. I played a ton of this in the demo and look forward to collecting even more fish in the full release. Game is simple. Buy packs of fish. Wait (or don't) for the fish to grow. Then sell the fish. To buy more packs of fish. To fill out a catalogue of all the different fish. You even have different rarities and colors of the fish, so there is a lot there for you to collect. If you like idlers, fish, and collecting, then this game is for you!

As the title says, this is a chill game. There's not much actual gameplay to be had, but it definitely scratches the gacha itch as you buy fish packs and watch your fish grow. An idle, gacha type game designed for single player is nice; there's a sort of zen knowing you're not actually in the competitive gacha bum rush to have a better set up than others. Definitely worth the low price if you're into this kind of thing.

I would like to stress again, though, that there's basically no gameplay except selling and opening the fish packs. You can feed and watch the fish rush towards the food, and that's it. There is no breeding, no playing with the fish, no marketplace or anything. It's a gacha simulator combined with a waiting/idle game, and it's pretty perfect for what it is, but it's not for everyone.

I already love chillquarium. Its a great little game where you feed and grow your fish to earn money to spend on more fish, the idleness is great. Id love to see more ways of interacting with your fish (I haven't gotten far so not sure if there is something like this in already) like leveling them up above their adult level, E.g adult level 2, which will just add another layer to getting attached to these lovely creatures. I will be putting a whole lot more time into this game but as it is new I wanted to give my first impressions; this game is great with little fault, the atmosphere and graphics of the fishes are stellar.
